content: Every ring homomorphism between fields is an injection and a ring monomorphism. Is this still true for ring homomorphisms between integral domains?
isn't Z→Z/2 \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}/2 Z→Z/2 a counter example?
Right, I forgot about that. Since the integers are the initial commutative ring, the unique ring homomorphism from the integers to any integral domain with prime characteristic is not injective.

But I think I am actually interested in ordered integral domains, so is it true that every ring homomorphism between ordered integral domains is an injection and a ring monomorphism? The ordering makes the integral domain have characteristic zero, so excludes the above example.
Is the fraction field of an ordered integral domain an ordered field?
How about evaluation at 000 from Z[T]→Z,\mathbb Z[T]\to\mathbb Z,Z[T]→Z, where TTT is infinitesimally small?
What order are you putting on Z[T]\mathbb Z[T]Z[T]?

I tried to show that one can have a non-injective ring homomorphism between two integral domains with characteristic zero. Let i:Z→Z[x]i: \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}[x]i:Z→Z[x] be the unique ring homomorphism, which sends a↦aa \mapsto aa↦a for all a∈Za \in \mathbb{Z}a∈Z. Note that Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] is an integral domain with characteristic zero.

We are looking for a map π:Z[x]→Z[x]/I\pi: \mathbb{Z}[x] \to \mathbb{Z}[x]/Iπ:Z[x]→Z[x]/I for some ideal III, such that π∘i\pi \circ iπ∘i is still injective. If π∘i\pi \circ iπ∘i is injective, that means that Z[x]/I\mathbb{Z}[x]/IZ[x]/I has characteristic zero. We also want Z[x]/I\mathbb{Z}[x]/IZ[x]/I to be an integral domain. We can ensure the quotient is an integral domain by choosing III to be a prime ideal.

To meet these two conditions simultaneously, we pick a prime ideal of III that doesn't include any integer multiples of 1. We set I=⟨x+1⟩I= \langle x+1 \rangleI=⟨x+1⟩. This should be a prime ideal as x+1x+1x+1 is an irreducible polynomial.

We then consider Z→iZ[x]→πZ[x]/⟨x+1⟩\mathbb{Z} \to_i \mathbb{Z}[x] \to_\pi \mathbb{Z}[x]/\langle x+1 \rangleZ→i​Z[x]→π​Z[x]/⟨x+1⟩. Since the image of iii is disjoint from the kernel of π\piπ, the composite map is injective. The injectivity of π∘i\pi \circ iπ∘i implies that Z[x]/⟨x+1⟩\mathbb{Z}[x]/\langle x+1 \rangleZ[x]/⟨x+1⟩ has characteristic zero. And since ⟨x+1⟩\langle x+1 \rangle⟨x+1⟩ is a prime ideal, Z[x]/⟨x+1⟩\mathbb{Z}[x]/\langle x+1 \rangleZ[x]/⟨x+1⟩ is an integral domain.

Therefore, π:Z[x]→Z[x]/⟨x+1⟩\pi: \mathbb{Z}[x] \to \mathbb{Z}[x]/\langle x+1 \rangleπ:Z[x]→Z[x]/⟨x+1⟩ is a non-injective ring homomorphism between integral domains with characteristic zero.

(Hopefully I didn't make a mistake! I'm also not sure how this relates to the desired result for ordered integral domains).
@Damiano Mazza I think saying TTT is infinitesimally small uniquely determines the order: a polynomial is positive if and only if its smallest-degree coefficient is positive.
@David Egolf, that works (for the non-ordered case), but there's an isomorphism of Z[x]/⟨x+1⟩\mathbb Z[x]/\langle x+1\rangleZ[x]/⟨x+1⟩ with a more familiar ring that would make it much clearer!

Kevin Arlin said:

a polynomial is positive if and only if its smallest-degree coefficient is positive.

Ok, thanks, you're right. Well then yours is definitely a counterexample!

Ah no, wait, is it? If TTT is infinitely small doesn't that mean that Z[T]\mathbb Z[T]Z[T] is not an integral domain? I'm taking "infinitely small" to mean something like Tk=0T^k=0Tk=0 for some k>1k>1k>1. But that must not be it. What do you mean then?
No, I mean infinitely small in the sense that kT<1kT<1kT<1 for every integer k.k.k.

This kind of construction is a standard way of getting at a "poor man's" approximation to, say, hyperreal numbers: you want a field containing R\mathbb RR and also some infinitely small ε,\varepsilon,ε, so try R(T)\mathbb R(T)R(T) and just define TTT to be infinitely small (but still invertible!)
Nice!!! Thanks, I had never seen this.
Sure :)

Kevin Arlin said:

David Egolf, that works (for the non-ordered case), but there's an isomorphism of Z[x]/⟨x+1⟩\mathbb Z[x]/\langle x+1\rangleZ[x]/⟨x+1⟩ with a more familiar ring that would make it much clearer!

Thanks for pointing that out! After a bit of thought, I think the evaluation homomorphism f:Z[x]→Zf: \mathbb{Z}[x] \to \mathbb{Z}f:Z[x]→Z at x=−1x=-1x=−1 should also have the properties we want. (That is, it is a non-injective ring homomorphism between integral domains with characteristic zero).

The kernel of this map is ⟨x+1⟩\langle x+1 \rangle⟨x+1⟩ and its image is all of Z\mathbb{Z}Z, so I think we have an isomorphism Z[x]/⟨x+1⟩≅Z\mathbb{Z}[x]/\langle x+1 \rangle \cong \ZZ[x]/⟨x+1⟩≅Z given by evaluating any representative at x=−1x=-1x=−1.
Yep, that's what I was thinking.

Damiano Mazza said:

What order are you putting on Z[T]\mathbb Z[T]Z[T]?

Kevin Arlin said:

Damiano Mazza I think saying TTT is infinitesimally small uniquely determines the order: a polynomial is positive if and only if its smallest-degree coefficient is positive.

One can also take TTT to be any transcendental real number and consider Z[T]\mathbb{Z}[T]Z[T] to be the commutative subring of the real numbers generated by TTT; this ring is an integral domain because the real numbers do not have zero divisors, and the order relation is inherited from the order relation of the real numbers.
I thought of that too but I actually don’t think it works. WLOG let T=π.T=\pi.T=π. Then the desired homomorphism is antitone when applied to 333 and 4−π,4-\pi,4−π, for instance.
In particular these are isomorphic rings but not isomorphic ordered rings.
The homomorphisms were never required to be monotone, but it doesn't hurt that you found an example where it is.
Oh, funny, right!
